text: From notes. Enjoyed at Dougs house for the Whale Tasting and Poker Night, almost 18 months in planning. 500 mL bottle. The pour is a slightly cloudy golden yellow with a thin white head that leaves a little lace as it falls. The aroma is surprisingly lactic. There is a heavy citrus, both fruit flesh and zest with a nice sourness and a hint of oakiness. The flavor is much of the same. There is a light funkiness to it with the citrus about it and a light gueuze character. Its not too complex, but its slightly prevalent. The sourness is nice, but I think its a little more funky than I would like. The mouth feel is light and clean with a softer carbonation and a lingeringly funky citrus on the back end. This is pretty good, but just needs a touch of work.
Seems to have mellowed with times, that makes it a smooth drinker. A good spotferm with tastes farmhouse - geuze characteristics. Cheers to whoever sent me this gem. Good carbonation, still.
At Zwanze Day 2014 at West Lakeview Liquors. Moderately acidic, good funk. Looking forward to where this beer heads over the years.
Bottle at Christmas, thanks to adnielsen. Pours a golden color with white head. Funky, cheese, sour aromas. Sour, funky, acidic flavors. I think I like the 2015 better.

Bottle in Winter Park with jcnielsen. Thanks Adam! Pours a cloudy yellow appearance with a thin white head. Aroma has some lactic acid, cheese, lots of citrus, lemon, and a bit of oak. Moderately sour. Lots of vanilla, oak, lemon citrus in the mouth. Fair amount of oak on the back end. Carbonation is a bit low. Sort of This is pretty on par with Casey Oak Theory though not quite as good.

2014 bottle labelled as a golden ale, shared at the 2016 end of year Ottawa tasting. Clear golden pour with no head. Light funk, some dried leather, grass, brett and epson salts, flaky lemon zest and some candied papaya. moderate carbonation and body, dry, tart and funky, nice to have shared.

A hazed golden Gueuze with a thin white head. In aroma, very nice tart ground cherries with light Epsom salts, light Brett, light lactic notes, very nice. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity Gueuze with light cherry tartness, light Epsom salts, very nice. Bottle at Ottawa Xmas gathering 2016.

500ml from the brewery. Opened December 2016. Not much of a head. Filtered tan. body. Bright, lemony, sharp, acidic aroma. Has some pleasant depth, I get flashbacks of the Wild Sour, but overall this has a cleaner Golden Ale backdrop. Delicious stuff, lots of subtleties.

Pours rather clear blonde, good white head, much visual carbonation. Smell is funk, lambic-like, bit more lactic though. Taste is sour, full, oak ( especially towards the aftertaste). Bit dry, mild lactic . Full in taste. not as complex as the real Oude Geuze, but a very good effort ! NG can proudly call themselves amongst the top of American sours.
Bottle shared by a friend. Clear yellow pour with a thick white head. Aroma of malt, funk and sourness. Malty and lemony flavor with a sour citrus finish.
UPDATED: JUN 15, 2016 Bottle - pours straw gold white head - nose/taste of lemon, oak, light sour funk and sweet Asian pear  - medium body.
500ml bottle pours out a hazy gold topped with a small white head. nose is citrus lemon buggy and some sweetness. taste is more of the buggy funk burning plastic.

Courtesy of Darshan
Bottle: The aroma consists of funky citrus, cheese, and lemon. It pours a slightly hazy dull yellow with a small white head that quickly fades to a minimal film outlined by a thin ring. The flavor starts with moderate sour citrus with a hint of cotton candy in the middle. The finish has moderate sour lemon, lemon peel, and a hint of vanilla. Its light-medium bodied with moderate carbonation.
Bottle split with the DB boyz. Unclear golden pour with a small head. Notes of apple skin, citrus, lime zest, red apples, very light balsamico, oaky vanilla and some musty wood. Gewd!

Bottle thanks to Lukas and Erik! Pours hazy golden yellow with a white head. Aroma of vinegar, apples, oak, horse blanket, funk and some pear. The taste is acidic and tart with notes of vinegar, horse blanket, funk, goose berries, and green apples. Good stuff!

Bottle thanks to Bursprak and Lukasmh! Pours hazy yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is full of gooseberries, citrussy, green apples, light vegetable-notes, funky, oaky. Taste has a lot of green apple sourness, oaky, funky, citrussy, vinegary, light lactic, lemony.

Tasted on 3/26/16 from a capped 500mL bottle, big thanks to Drews for sharing. Pours hazy bright orangey yellow with a very thick white head that slowly recedes to average lace. The nose is tart, plenty of soft citrus, just a very light hint of some funky horse blanket, and a touch of rubber. The flavor is more orange, juicy, just a bit of tartness and the same horse blanket adding complexity. The body is medium with average carbonation, a bit of tannin grip, and a long tart orange juice and lightly funky finish.

bottle shared by a friend. poured a slight cloudy yellow to golden colour with a slight white head on top. nose is moderate sour, old dust, grains, citrus, lots of white grapes, oak, tart green apples, funky tart notes, slight spiced brett. nice crisp refreshing brew.
Hazy yellow pour. Nose is lemon, some funk. Taste is pulpy lemon, funky. Light spritzy mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2016  January 16, 2016. Bottle, received in a trade with craftbeer1over, thanks! 
Hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is lemon, brett, overripe fruits, funk, green apples, funk, barnyard and hints of grain.
Taste is tart, fruity and funky. Finish is light dry, fruity and bretty with some lemon, funk, green apple and a touch of barnyard. Medium bodied, soft to average carbonation. 
Very good.
A: Light yellow, white head dissapears right away. N: Lemon, zest, green apples T: Lemon, zest, apple, pear O: This is so nice! Extremly well balanced!

Bottle at Happy New Beer in Sätila 160116. Hazy yellow/apricot color, no head. Fruity funky aroma, leather, grapes, rubber notes, orange zest, fruity, citrus, grapefruit notes. Sour rubber flavor, earthy, funky, grapes, raisins, some leather. Good lambic.
Bottle. Pours hazy pale golden with a small head. Aroma is clean crisp fruity funky a bit stable. Flavor is crisp fruity funky slightly sweet...crushable

Bottle courtesy of hackobock. Pours hazy yellow with a rather small frothy and fizzy white head that doesnt leave much trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is subtle, tiny fruity and slightly funky with crackers, lemon juice, unripe pears, yoghurt, hay, dry soil, barnyard and lemon zest. Taste is sour, slightly fruity and funky. Mouthfeel is dry tart and light to medium bodied. Finish is sour with crackers, lemon juice, green apples, pears, yoghurt, hay, dry soil, barnyard and lemon zest. Sublte and sublime with an elegance in the sourness thats hard to match. I had high expectations and this lives up to them.

Hazy blonde appearance, with healthy clinging foam. Many appropriate references to classic gueuze in this high quality American sour; buoyant stone fruit characteristics, sharp gravelly dryness, some oceanic brine action, balanced well and coalescing into a very convincing rendition. Highly attenuated body, feathery and crisp but fulsome. Its missing a certain intangible aliveness, the it factor of the great lambics, highly enjoyable regardless.

500 ml AdamC. In our most recent tasting. Hazy gold, no head. Aroma of white grape, old lemons, slightly funky yeast. 
I enjoy the flavor much more then the aroma. Tart lemons, old yeast, and slightly aged cheese. The body is medium with a yeasty/ chewy texture. It also becomes very dry after a few sips. No vinegar notes, which is beautiful. Ver nicely done!

Knocking down the R and Ds! 500ml bottle shared by AdamChandler. Thanks, Adam! Pours white straw gold, white head. Nice citrus aroma, mild floral. Flavor is lime citrus, mild funk, mild floral. Tart finish.
Poured from bottle thanks AdamChandler hazy yellow pour with no head. Aromas of tart citrus green apple. Taste follows aroma with notes of peach.

500ML Bottle split 5 ways. Acquired in a trade.

A - A very light small hazy yellow with no head. 

S - Aroma has just a faint sour-ness, not very extreme sour with some vinegar and green apple

T - Well balanced sour taste with lemon, lime, apple and peach and then theres a sharp apple cider vinegar taste that comes in at the middle

M - Refined, balanced mouthfeel as well. Its not overcarbed, it has an overall just well dont mouthfeel

O - These R&D beers tend to be very close to Lambic. This one is no surprise.

Poured a lightly hazy golden color with a white head. Aroma of grass, lemon juice, brett, damp rocks, light grain and fruit. Flavor was incredibly drinkable, lightly less complex than a traditional geueze, but less tart and crushable.
Shared by Charule. Pours a clearish golden yellow with a slight white head. Aromas of light vinegar and white wine. Taste is slightly sour. All very one note but a good American version of the style.
Bottle from release at NG. Poured clear gold with white head. Aroma sweet grape skin musky. Light carb med bod. Tastes yeasty light tart.

Pours a slightly hazy light yellow golden color without much head at all. Funk, tartness, citrus, hay, barnyard, and light fruits on the nose; follows onto the palate. Light bodied. Finishes tart, dry, and crisp.

500 ml bottle via trade. Pours a hazy gold color with no head. Notes of oak, sawdust, lemon, celery, lime, farmhouse funk, dust, light vinegar, and cobwebs. Light-medium bodied, with medium carbonation that gives it a sneaky spritziness and a tart, funky, oaky mouthfeel. Dry, sharp finish. Very nice take on the style. Well done.

500ml bottle, thanks to phaleslu for sharing. Totally hazy golden orange color. Thin white ring of head. Fantastic funky oak, and "horse", yeah. Nice bit of lemon citrus, great big oak. Moderate-plus sour taste, light sweet, mild dry. A wonderful, funky gueuze-style ale. This seems to be more with the gueuze flavor, than the typical gueuze sourness, which I dont mind at all. All of the 4 2015 R & D bottles I tried tonight... They were actually way less sour than I expected, judging from the wild blackberry sour that I will never forget. But they all had awesome aroma profiles, which I really appreciate.

Tangy citrus, a hint of cheese (not really, but seems to come and go), some vinegar; yellow color, thin white head; flavor is more tart and less acidic than I would have expected, funky, powdered berry before the finish, yeasty, fruity, complex, ; medium light body, nicely carbonated; really nice blend, extremely flavorful and drinkable.

500ml bottle from the brewery. Pours a clear, golden color with a thin white head. Aroma is fruity, lemon, oak, funk. Medium on the palate with light, creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet tart, oak, sour fruit, lemon, grapefruit, some light funk, some sour apple, with a light sour finish. Very Gueuze-like, more so than most American brewed beers. Could use a little more sour funk, but its a small knock. Very well done.

Bottle @ La Palma Sour Fest 2015. Thanks for sending this my way, Shawn. Hazed golden colored beer with white foam. There is a strong yogurt, lemon, and green grape quality up front. Slight musty funk along with a bit of an iron/mineral note. Maybe a little bit of a sweet stone fruit and citrus thing going on too. Bright lemon, green apple, and green grape finish. A nice one.
500 ml. bottle. Thanks Al. Pours a hazy pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of fruit, funk, and wood. Taste is grape, apple, citrus, funk, and oak. Nice.

Pour from bottle at GABF 2015. Pour is clear golden with a big white head and sticky lacing. Super funky, uriney, slightly cheesy, citrusy, some lemons, tangy, and oaky aroma. Taste is super funky, waxy, cheesy, hay, some barnyard notes, lemons, oak, and lactic with a lightly tart finish. Full mouthfeel with high carbonation. Another great R&D offering from New Glarus. Very lambic-esque - super complex and refreshing.

Bottle poured at GABF 2015 with Andrew, Mel and Frank. Mouthfeel is tart and sour with notes of tart oak, minerality character, white wine, sour fruit, aged cheese and funk. Great stuff and another memorable offering of the weekend.
Bottle. Hazy golden pour with white head. Light fruit, wine, oak and tart aromas. Dry wine, oak, cherries and other sweet fruit, finish is dry.

Bottle 500ml. Thx Cartman.
Pours slightly hazy blond with low to no head white head. Aroma is of sourness, some vinegar, citrus, cheese. Taste is of sourness, fruits, very nice acid, citrus. Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. Somewhat dry feeling. Is this oak? Overall: Surprisingly good. Sourness and acidity are well integrated.

Bottle shared by tom10101, thanks man! It pours. A hazy pale golden with a thin white head that leaves zero lacing. Nose is of vinegar, rubber and fruits. Taste is fruity, moderately sour and dry. Light vinegar but nothing bad. Body is medium, carbonation medium-high. Overall a more than fair american sour, not a gueuze though.

pours hazy very light golden with a small white cap, some retention and lacing. peppery pears, some green apple notes, citrus peel and its acidity; light to medium acidity - complex flora but not quite gueuze-y; lots of lactic though, sulfur grassiness, autumn leaves, white pepper. average to light carbonation, light body; dry and tart herbal-grassy finish. not quite genuine but a very nice and fairly complex tart blend.

How: Bottle (500 ml) at czars place. 

>>> An interesting fruity sour with interesting cheesy notes but it lacks of depth and its not so gueuze-ish.

-  Clear bright golden with a small ring of white foam and little lacing. 
-  Quite fruity (peaches, apricots) with cheesy notes. 
-  Theres some herbal (almost vegetal) and mineral notes as secondary flavors. 
-  Well balanced, theres a nice acidic presence, but nothing harsh. 
-  Light to medium body, bordeline watery. Moderate carbonation. Short aftertaste, a bit bland. 
-  Easy drinking and refreshing. 

Flavors:  Fruits (apricots, peaches), cheesy notes, herbal presence, mild acidic, mineral notes.

Bottle. Pours hazy pale golden, small white head, fizzy with some lacing. Aroma is funk forward, sweat socks, oak, gueuze notes. Flavor is light sweet, hints of white grape, oak, light funk. Light body. Decent.
Clear golden color. Grapey saison, sour aroma, some funk. Tingly mouthfeel. Tastes like champagne meets white grape juice. Alright.
Bottle shared. Murky golden pour. Aroma is funky, green apple, berries and grain. Taste is quite sour and light sweet. Light to medium body.

bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis.
Thin white head. Barnyard funk aroma. Tart sourness

Bottle shared. Pours cloudy light orange with a medium white head. Aroma of citrus, light veggies notes, lentil, light funk and tart fruit. Flavour is over moderate sour. Light medium bodied with light carbonation.

Bottle shared by kermis. Hazy very pale gold pour with creamy white head. Aroma is slightly vegetal, a bit of lentils, light peach, mild funk, light cheesy notes. Taste is citric, fruity, light flour, light breadiness. Palate is light bodied, very dry, sharp carb. Decent.
Bottle...Pour is golden with a white head..Nose is musty, tart, spice, lemon, old hop..Taste is lemon, spice, light tartness, spice, funk, funk..
Bottle. Yellow pour with a white head. Muted barnyard bouquet. A bit watery with muted funk. Not too much there IMHO. Average body and mouthfeel.

500 mL bottle poured into a snifter. Clear straw color. Small white head. Really nice aroma. Lemon. Bright oak. Hay. White wine? Nice. Tastes nicely tart. White wine is very prominent here. Oak permeates throughout. Hay and dried grass finish. Medium low carbonation. For an American sour, its really nice and complex. If it were a true Belgian lambic, it probably wouldnt rank that highly.
Bottle thanks to Chow. Pours a hazy yellow gold with no head. The aroma is strong funk, apple skin, brett. Thin mouth, tart, funk, brett, light finish, really nice.

Sampled from the bottle at GTMW 2015. Pours a hazy light gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of sour fruits with a light sweetness and an oak and funk backing. Flavor has a nice funk note with sour fruit, a growing acid and a bit of funk.

500 ml bottle acquired from the brewery (New Glarus, WI). Pours a hazy golden bright hue, a touch of fiery orange, firmer whitish head atop is sizable, a nice firmer layer dies down quickly, a nice ringer sits atop, soapy with solid lacing throughout. Aromas are tart and lactic, stone fruit and straw meet yogurt, rustic grain and mellow tannic oak. Cobwebs, terroir funkiness meet some white grape, tart crab apple and a bit of fuzziness. Subtle melon, more grape and citric jabs. Initial is lighter in body, smoothed out fruit and melon, citrus and tart apple meet yogurt, earth and gentle straw and bready malts. Subtle grain, some punchy lactic life is a bit sour, white grape and a touch of lemon. Citric and lactic acidity melds into this one well. A bit dry, twangy. Light bodied, subtle carbonation that cuts through at times, at others the acidity rises up a bit and waves over the palate more firmly. A faint waft of pineapple, pear. A bit dry, subtle spice and oaky presence as we round the corner, touches of vanilla and tannic oak meet faint white wine, a bit more yogurt. Some funkiness, yeasty life. More yogurty and trailing fruit finish. A bit dry, lighter. I dig this. A nice blend, no element really every becomes too much or takes the lead, with a more tart, fruity nose that leads into a more expert integration, sour and fruity, yogurty twang with more of a tannic, subtle sweet trail out and young funk profile. Some slick sour lactic presence remains on the palate, a touch twangy/metallic. This one is ready to go right out of the gate. However itll be fun to follow how this one develops that brett and funk character as it grows older. A nice pour, nose and fun progression. Fun new one from the R&D Series.

Bottle - Pours golden with a ring of white head. Nose is lemon funk, hay, a bit of apple, and some vinegar tartness. Taste is hay, lemon sour, funk, and a dry, bitter, citrus rind finish. Fluffy and soft body with ample carbonation. Decent stuff.
Pour at the Great Taste of the Midwest. Hazy light yellow pour with a white head. Funky nose. Lightly tart, lots of funk. Dry barnyard finish. Nice (enjoyed 2 pours!).

Bottle sample at GTMW 2015. Hazy to cloudy golden yellow color, creamy off white head. Aroma od dusty barns and attic corners. Taste has softly sour dhusty and peppery hay, straw, overripe summer fruit. Delicious.

Bottled. Poured hazy medium golden with a short-lived white head. The aroma picked up sour vinegar and lemon zest with a soft bready base.. very nice. The flavor found lemon rind, horseblanket, and vinegar, again with pale base.. finished sour and lemony. Lighter-bodied and sour.. well-balanced.

Bottle via Wrye, thanks again for bringing this one! Pours a light orange with moderate sized white head. Aroma is funky, barn yard and horse blanket. Really one of the best, if not the best, America gueuze Ive had. Taste is again funky and a bit more sour than the traditional gueuze but truly amazing that New Glarus has once again pulled off a crazy good beer.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
Rating from memory, cashed both of my bottles during a recent trip to Wisconsin. Pours a clear light blonde with a small, dissipating head. Aroma is tart apple and moderate barnyard earthiness. Flavor is largely tart, with green apple, horsey notes. Crisp, sparkling palate.

Well worth the trip to New Glarus.
Hazed yellow, white head. Nice and sour. Good funk, light oaky notes. A tad more sour and less earthy than the gueuze overseas.
500ml bottle. Clear golden pour with almost no head. Strong funk and lemon aroma. Taste follows, very delicious. Great gueuze.
Bottle shared by Tom - thanks! Mostly clear golden yellow pour with a small ring head. Funky horseblanket, lemon, lively palate - this is excellent!

Gold pour with a fluffy yet smallish white head. Dusty cobweb like aroma, leather, hay, white grape, lemon, and sweet candied fruit notes I cant quite grasp. Up front finish is quite tart yet a light sweetness and a touch of earthy bitterness and grain peaking towards the end.

Opened my bottle the night I brought it home. First thing I noticed is I poured it hard, but really couldnt get much of a head. What head I did get, dissipated rapidly. Besides that, the color was and body was beautiful. Aroma was a funky barnyard. Hints of lemon and fruit. Wow was the taste great. Not too sour, did not pucker you up. Smooth lemon citrus taste.

500ml, released today. Mild sourness, lemon, tart. No sweetness. Bit of barnyard funk. Mild, but perfectly balanced. Amazingly drinkable. Seriously, should have enjoyed it slower, downed it in no time. Right now its drinking like an amazing Berliner, would like to see this develop in the same manner as sour fruit and wild peach.
